an3.127:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an3.127:4.2: Then, late at night, the beautiful god Hatthaka, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha.
an3.127:4.4: “I will stand before the Buddha,” he sank and melted down, and wasn’t able to stay still.
an3.127:4.5: It’s like when ghee or oil is poured on sand, it sinks and melts down, and can’t stay still.
an3.127:5.1: Then the Buddha said to Hatthaka:
an3.127:5.3: “Yes, sir,” replied Hatthaka. He manifested in a solid life-form, bowed to the Buddha, and stood to one side.
an3.127:6.1: “Hatthaka, I wonder whether you still rehearse now the teachings that you rehearsed when you were a human being?”
an3.127:6.2: “I still rehearse now the teachings that I rehearsed as a human being.
an3.127:6.3: And I also rehearse teachings that I didn’t rehearse as a human being.
an3.127:6.4: Just as the Buddha these days lives crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and teachers of other paths and their disciples,
an3.127:6.5: so I live crowded by the gods.
an3.127:6.6: The gods come from far away, thinking, ‘We’ll hear the teaching in the presence of Hatthaka.’
an3.127:6.7: Sir, I died without getting enough of three things.
an3.127:6.12: I died without getting enough of these three things.”
an3.127:8.2: loving to hear the true teaching,
an3.127:8.3: Hatthaka has gone to the Aviha realm
an3.127:8.4: without getting enough of these three things.”
